Evaluate the expression at the critical points to find the smallest value.

Express the given function f(a, b) = a^2 + ab + b^2 - 3a - 3b in a more manageable form.
Calculate the partial derivatives of the function f(a, b) with respect to a and b.
Set the partial derivatives equations to zero to find the critical points of the function f(a, b).
Substitute the critical points back into the function f(a, b) to evaluate their values.
Identify the nature of these critical points (i.e., minimum, maximum, or saddle point) using second derivative test or other suitable method.
Determine the smallest value among the function values calculated at the critical points.
Consider the behavior of the function f(a, b) at the boundaries or infinity, if necessary, to ensure the smallest value found is the global minimum.
